Headline.Para: Dystopia is closer than you think

Snippet.Para: The overused dystopian premise in some science-fiction stories is so badly thought out that perhaps writers can seek inspiration from Singapore

Headline.Para: Dystopia is closer than you think

LeadPara.Para: The overused dystopian premise in some science-fiction stories is so badly thought out that perhaps writers can seek inspiration from Singapore
The big movie Ready Player One is opening this week.

TailParas.Para: Like many science-fiction stories, the 2011 novel on which it is based has a dystopia premise. Earth is a wasteland. Everyone is living in virtual reality, plugged into headsets that let them escape the horrors of living on a planet blasted by global warming and overpopulation.
Dystopias are so hot these days (in the sense that they are trendy, not because they use global warming as a plot device).
In Blade Runner 2049 (2017), for example, people eat worm protein because of ecological collapse, the poor live in junkyards and rich, talented people live "off-world".
On a side note: In Singapore, we drink water made from waste; do we live in a dystopia?

In The Walking Dead television series, anyone who is not a zombie is busy killing people from other tribes. It's much the same in Mad Max: Fury Road (2015) and so it goes for The Hunger Games (2012), The Maze Runner (2014) and so on.
I get it: We are not supposed to examine science-fiction premises too closely if we want to enjoy books and movies. The suspension of disbelief and all that.
ST ILLUSTRATION: CEL GULAPA
But enough is enough. Not only am I getting dystopia overload, but I am also weary of fake, lazy dystopias and all that rubbish hand-waving that comes with it.

To explain what I mean, take a look at a franchise like Star Trek. I am no Trek geek but, as far as I know, there are no dystopias in the Trek-verse. Because it makes sense that if you can fly faster than light and can beam people across space, you can fix global warming and stop white rhinos from dying out.
Like my mother says, if you're going to be that clever with me at home, why are you so dumb in school?
And that is what bugs me about Ready Player One by American writer Ernest Cline.

The same problem plagues Blade Runner 2049 and any other franchises where in one narrow sliver of life, there exists mind-bogglingly advanced technology. But somehow, that know-how has not trickled down into other areas.

If you can terraform the moons of Saturn, you don't have to eat worm paste for dinner. If you have flying cars and virtual girlfriends, you can move people out of junkyards and into nice public housing estates.

In too many science-fiction franchises, the dystopia premise is unnecessary. Authors chuck it in for no good reason. They could have been eating nice whole wheat muffins in Blade Runner 2049, for all the difference it made to the story.

In The Maze Runner, the dystopia concept was put in to give the teens a hard time. If you want to really give teens a hard time, tell them that the examinations they take at age 12 will set their path for the rest of their lives.
Let's fix some science-fiction stories, shall we? Make them less dystopia-heavy and apply some good, old Singapore-style town planning.
THE WALKING DEAD
Current premise: The world is overrun by zombies. Warring tribes fight for remaining resources.

New premise: After some early panic, things settle down and we set up some ZNTs (Zombie New Towns), where the living dead are resettled. Zombies soon become the backbone of our construction and tree-planting industries because they don't need sleep and have a never-say-die attitude. The living complain about the dead stealing their jobs.
BLADE RUNNER 2049:

Current premise: People who have escaped the dying Earth. Scrapyard people live in the polluted zones while the rest live in teeming cities. Rather than find mates made of flesh, people are turning to virtual-reality companions.

New premise: The Government imposes heavy levies called COEEs (Certificates of Erotic Entitlement) on virtual mates because they are hurting the birthrate. Parliament considers laws restricting the use of flying e-scooters because too many uncles are buying them and becoming sky nuisances.
READY PLAYER ONE:
Current premise: Global warming and overpopulation drive everyone into a virtual world created by powerful corporations, where they hang out, work and play games.

New premise: Corporations sell everything they know about your online life to political parties, who use the data to create memes and talking points that get their xenophobic, hate-spewing puppet politicians elected.
On second thought, maybe dystopias aren't that far-fetched after all.
